name: Energy-Mass Equivalence
what: This subtopic covers Einstein's famous equation E = mc² and how it explains the enormous energy locked within matter. You will learn how nuclear reactions convert small amounts of mass into vast quantities of energy.
why: Understanding energy-mass equivalence is fundamental to explaining how nuclear power plants and nuclear weapons work, and why nuclear fuels release millions of times more energy than chemical fuels like coal.

items.title: I can explain that nuclear energy results from the conversion of mass to energy
items.what: Nuclear energy is released when a small amount of mass is converted into energy according to Einstein's equation E = mc². Both fission and fusion reactions involve this mass-to-energy conversion.
items.why: This principle explains why nuclear fuels contain so much more energy per kilogram than chemical fuels, and forms the basis for understanding all nuclear technologies.
items.example: When uranium-235 undergoes fission, about 0.1% of its mass is converted to energy. If 1.0 kg of uranium-235 completely fissions, 1.0 g of mass becomes 9.0 × 10¹³ J of energy.

items.title: I can use E = mc² to calculate energy released from mass conversion
items.what: The equation E = mc² relates the energy released (E in joules) to the mass converted (m in kilograms) and the speed of light squared (c² = 9 × 10¹⁶ m² s⁻²).
items.why: Being able to calculate energy from mass difference allows you to quantify the enormous energy released in nuclear reactions and compare nuclear to chemical energy sources.
items.example: A nuclear bomb converts 0.7 g of mass to energy: E = (7 × 10⁻⁴)(9 × 10¹⁶) = 63 × 10¹² J = 63 TJ, equivalent to about 15 kilotonnes of TNT.

items.title: I can compare the energy released by nuclear reactions versus chemical reactions
items.what: Nuclear reactions release approximately one million times more energy per kilogram than chemical reactions because the strong nuclear force is much stronger than electromagnetic forces binding electrons.
items.why: This comparison explains why a small uranium pellet can release as much energy as burning a tonne of coal, making nuclear energy so concentrated.
items.example: Burning 1.0 kg of coal releases 3.0 × 10⁷ J with a mass loss of 0.33 μg. Fissioning 1.0 kg of uranium-235 releases 9.0 × 10¹³ J with a mass loss of 1.0 g, about 3 million times more energy.

items.title: I can explain the difference between chemical and nuclear burning of fuels
items.what: Chemical burning rearranges outer electrons (bound by electromagnetic force, a few eV). Nuclear burning rearranges nucleons (bound by the strong force, millions of eV). Both involve mass-to-energy conversion.
items.why: Understanding this distinction clarifies why nuclear fuels are so much more energy-dense and why nuclear reactions fundamentally differ from ordinary combustion.
items.example: In coal combustion, carbon and oxygen electrons rearrange. In uranium fission, the nucleus itself splits apart, releasing binding energy that was holding the nucleons together.
